CASE 94:
DISCLOSURE OF DIAGNOSIS AND CULTURAL
RELATIVISM
An 85-year-old Japanese man, Aiko, who came to the UK 10 years ago to live with his chil-
dren, is admitted with haematuria. He has known bladder cancer but has been under sur-
veillance with regular cystoscopy for many years and during this time has had multiple
admissions with frank haematuria. These have usually been secondary to urinary tract infec-
tions. Unfortunately, on this occasion it is discovered that his bladder cancer has turned
aggressive and spread rapidly. He is found to have multiple metastases and it is likely that he
is in the terminal stage of his disease.
His son and daughter arrange a meeting with the oncologist and are insistent that their father
should not be informed of his prognosis, since they feel that he will ‘give up’. Rather, they ask
that ‘we should respect him and not directly tell him of his prognosis so that he might enjoy
the last part of his life’. The oncologist agrees to discuss their request with the other members
of the clinical team.
The palliative care nurse insists that the patient has a right to know so that any palliative
treatment that is given can be obtained with informed consent. The senior ward nurse takes
the view that the team should balance the risks and benefits of telling the truth to this patient.
The registrar believes that Aiko himself should be asked how much he wants to know.
Questions
• Is there a moral obligation to tell Aiko his prognosis?
• To what extent should cultural beliefs and practices influence your decision making?

data.vignette: An 85-year-old man originally from Japan is admitted with recurrent gross haematuria. He has longstanding bladder cancer under surveillance. Imaging and biopsy now show rapidly progressive disease with widespread metastases. The oncology team can offer symptom-focused care and, if he wishes, a short course of palliative chemotherapy that requires informed consent and may worsen fatigue and nausea. His son and daughter request a family meeting and insist you not tell him the prognosis. They say direct disclosure would cause despair and that their family tradition is to shield elders from bad news. The patient is alert and asks, “Is this just another infection?” Hospital policy and state law permit either direct disclosure to the patient or a family-mediated approach when the patient has not stated a preference. You must decide before tomorrow’s consent discussion.
data.choice_1: Tell the patient his terminal prognosis and discuss treatment options directly
data.choice_2: Follow the family’s request and avoid direct disclosure of the prognosis

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 a concrete, legally implementable order given that chemotherapy requires informed consent. For example, revise Choice 2 to either: (a) 'Ask the patient how much information he wants and whether he wants his family to receive details; if he prefers family-led disclosure, proceed with family-mediated discussion and document his preference,' OR (b) 'Defer/forgo palliative chemotherapy for now and provide symptom-focused care while communicating primarily with the family, without explicitly stating terminal prognosis to the patient.' Avoid an instruction that implies proceeding with chemotherapy while withholding material prognosis information from a capacitated patient.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add key facts needed to frame the ethical stakes without turning it into a clinical debate: (1) whether the patient speaks English fluently or needs an interpreter; (2) whether he has previously stated preferences about receiving serious news (e.g., prior oncology visits, advance directive, prior conversations); (3) confirmation of decision-making capacity; (4) whether the family is requesting active deception vs simply requesting that prognosis be discussed first with them; and (5) what the consent discussion tomorrow is for (starting chemo vs deciding on hospice-only). Remove any non-essential demographic detail if it does not affect the dilemma.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Strengthen legal grounding so both options are clearly permissible despite informed-consent requirements. Add a sentence such as: 'State law allows patients to delegate receipt of medical information to family if they choose; if the patient declines detailed prognostic information, chemotherapy can still be offered with disclosure focused on goals, burdens, and alternatives.' Alternatively, if withholding prognosis would invalidate consent, modify Choice 2 so it does not involve initiating chemotherapy until the patient’s information preferences are documented or until he delegates decision-making.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes:
Make the ethical conflict unavoidable (remove the easy third option of simply asking the patient his disclosure preference).
- Add a sentence that an in-person professional interpreter is unavailable until after tomorrow’s chemo-consent deadline, and the patient speaks limited English, so you cannot reliably explore nuanced preferences without using the family.
- OR state that the patient will likely lose decision-making capacity overnight (e.g., planned sedation for urgent procedure or escalating encephalopathy), so there is no time to elicit and document his wishes about disclosure.
- OR explicitly state that when gently asked about how much detail he wants, he gives no clear preference and repeatedly defers to his children, leaving you to choose the disclosure approach.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes:
Clarify the core conflict without leaning on legal/policy permissiveness, which can shift graders toward a compliance/legality reading rather than an ethics reading.
- Replace “Hospital policy and state law permit either…” with a neutral clinical fact such as: “Both direct disclosure and family-mediated disclosure are used in this hospital when patients have not stated a preference.”
- Add 1–2 concrete, value-relevant consequences that most readers will recognize (e.g., risk of the patient feeling betrayed later if shielded; risk of acute distress and loss of trust if told bluntly against family’s wishes).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Strengthen the ethical defensibility of Choice 2 and add moral costs to Choice 1 so neither option is an obvious default.
- For Choice 1 (direct disclosure), add a realistic downside beyond generic “despair,” e.g., the patient has a history of severe depression after prior losses or becomes panicked/delirious with stressful conversations, and the family provides essential bedside support and may disengage if you override them.
- For Choice 2 (family-mediated non-disclosure), make it more clinically plausible while still ethically costly: specify you would use a structured family-mediated approach (with a professional interpreter if available) that conveys seriousness and options without explicit life-expectancy language unless the patient asks; note the risk that this may still compromise informed consent and later damage trust.
- Ensure both choices explicitly entail a tradeoff: Choice 2 should not read like simple paternalism; it should be framed as a culturally concordant communication strategy with potential to reduce immediate suffering, at the cost of limiting patient-led decision-making.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace value-laden phrasing that favors disclosure or portrays the family as coercive. For example: change “insist you not tell him” to “ask that you not disclose the prognosis directly,” and change “would cause despair” to “would be distressing.” Consider neutralizing the cultural framing by stating “the family cites cultural and personal beliefs about disclosure” rather than implying a single ‘tradition’.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Reduce potentially identifying or stereotyped details by generalizing the patient’s background (e.g., “born abroad” or “from an East Asian cultural background”) unless clinically necessary. Avoid phrasing that reads like a classic ‘family asks to withhold bad news’ exemplar by adding one or two case-specific details (e.g., prior conversations about information preferences, language/interpretation needs) while keeping identifiers out.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Tighten and standardize choices to ~10–15 neutral words and ensure each states the full action without loaded terms. For example: 
- Choice 1: “Disclose prognosis to the patient and obtain consent directly for chemotherapy.” 
- Choice 2: “Use a family-mediated discussion and defer direct prognosis disclosure to the patient.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so Choice 2 is clinically/ethically defensible: (1) Add that the patient previously stated (and it’s documented) that he does not want detailed prognostic information and prefers his children to receive bad news first, OR that he explicitly wants a family-mediated approach when serious illness is discussed. (2) Remove/rephrase the patient’s direct prompt that implies he is seeking a truthful answer (e.g., change “Is this just another infection?” to a neutral symptom question like “Why am I bleeding again?” and show he does not press for details). (3) Clarify that palliative chemotherapy can still be consented to with discussion focused on symptom relief and side effects without explicit life-expectancy disclosure, so nondisclosure is not automatically incompatible with consent.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the obvious third option (ask the patient what he wants to know/how he wants information delivered). Add a constraint such as: (1) the patient will be sedated/undergo a procedure early tomorrow and will likely lose decision-making capacity before you can have an extended values conversation; (2) there is no qualified interpreter/cultural mediator available until after the consent deadline; and (3) you have already attempted to ask his preference today in a straightforward way (“Some people want all details; others want family to handle information—what do you prefer?”) and he declined to answer or said “You decide,” leaving only direct disclosure vs family-mediated nondisclosure for tomorrow’s consent discussion.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, standard informed-consent norms and professional guidance generally require disclosure to a capacitated patient unless the patient waives information; a family request alone is usually not sufficient. To keep this in the gray zone: (1) explicitly state that the patient previously executed a documented ‘information waiver’/preference for family-first disclosure, or that he consistently asked clinicians not to discuss prognosis with him; (2) clarify that hospital counsel/ethics has confirmed this practice is permissible in this jurisdiction when a patient has not requested disclosure and has a cultural preference for family-mediated communication; and (3) make clear that neither option violates policy—e.g., policy allows either direct disclosure or family-first disclosure with a plan to revisit the patient’s preference when feasible.

data.vignette: An 85-year-old man with recurrent gross hematuria is admitted for evaluation. He has bladder cancer that was followed with surveillance. Imaging and biopsy now show widely metastatic, rapidly progressive disease. He is alert and has decision-making capacity. He speaks limited English. His adult son and daughter usually interpret, and a professional interpreter is unavailable until after tomorrow. In prior oncology notes, he repeatedly stated that he does not want detailed prognostic information and prefers his children to hear serious news first and “tell me what I need to do.” A short course of palliative chemotherapy could reduce bleeding and pain but may cause fatigue and nausea, and hospice-only care is also an option. Early tomorrow he will undergo a sedated urologic procedure and may not be able to participate afterward, so the consent discussion must occur today. The family asks that you discuss prognosis with them first and avoid explicitly telling him he is dying. Hospital leadership has confirmed that either approach is permissible when a patient has documented family-first communication preferences.
data.choice_1: Disclose the terminal prognosis to the patient and obtain chemotherapy consent directly
data.choice_2: Use a family-mediated discussion and avoid explicit prognosis disclosure to the patient

choice_2.choice: Use a family-mediated discussion and avoid explicit prognosis disclosure to the patient

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating whether the patient is asked (today) to reaffirm his preference for family-first communication/right-not-to-know before proceeding with either approach.

Add a clause making the patient-welfare stakes of the disclosure approach explicit (e.g., that explicit prognosis disclosure today would likely cause him significant distress and refusal of symptom-relieving chemo, whereas family-mediated communication risks misunderstanding leading to unwanted burdensome treatment or delayed hospice).

Add a clause making the nonmaleficence harms of each option explicit (e.g., that direct disclosure today would be done without a professional interpreter and previously caused him marked anxiety/distress, and that family-mediated nondisclosure risks proceeding with chemotherapy he might refuse—exposing him to nausea/fatigue/complications without fully informed consent).

data.vignette: An 85-year-old man with recurrent gross hematuria is admitted for evaluation. He has bladder cancer that was followed with surveillance. Imaging and biopsy now show widely metastatic, rapidly progressive disease. He is alert and has decision-making capacity. He speaks limited English. His adult son and daughter usually interpret, and a professional interpreter is unavailable until after tomorrow. Today, when asked to confirm his preferences with family interpretation, he again indicates that he does not want detailed prognostic information and wants his children to hear serious news first and guide next steps. A short course of palliative chemotherapy could reduce bleeding and pain but may cause fatigue and nausea, and hospice-only care is also an option. Early tomorrow he will undergo a sedated urologic procedure and may not be able to participate afterward, so the consent discussion must occur today. Direct disclosure today may cause distress and confusion without a professional interpreter and could lead him to decline symptom-relieving treatment. Family-mediated communication may better match his stated preference but risks misunderstandings and proceeding with burdensome chemotherapy or delaying hospice. Hospital leadership has confirmed that either approach is permissible when a patient has documented family-first communication preferences.

choice_1.choice: Disclose the terminal prognosis to the patient and obtain chemotherapy consent directly

choice_2.choice: Use a family-mediated discussion and avoid explicit prognosis disclosure to the patient
